lines.text:
[narrating]
I know about ships. They're wood and metal and nothing else. They don't have souls. They don't have wills of their own. And they don't talk back.
But don't forget I'm in this with you and Birdie.
Look, let me deal with the sordid details. They're right my street. You're happy with the ship. I'll leave that to you.
Okay, I'm responsible for 1087. Then I'd better know what she's expected to do.
Oooh! For Pete's sake, is the ship goin' to have a say in the kinds of jobs we take on?
She won't ask any questions certainly.
Like the ideal woman, aay? She does what you want when you want it. If we knew the way and could set a course for Hell, she'd go!

[referring to a suspicious-looking passenger]
I wonder who the devil he is!
Let's just say 500 quid and leave it at that!
You said the jobs were getting worse. You're right. Last night was too much!
[he crushes the newspaper in his hands]
We'll get out!
Do you really believe we can get out now?... finish? Clean off the muck and forget what we've done? Do you really believe that?
Why not?

Because it happened! We did those things! From the smuggling of a few bottles of wine in the early days to the carrying of that raving maniac last night! We did it all, George, and we can't wipe that off the scoreboard!
She won't do it... not after what we made her do, not after that! She's got her pride - like all of us! She won't do it! You can't blame her!
No, Birdie, I don't blame her.
You'll never get away with this!
Let's try, shall we?
[last lines]

[narrating]
And so she died. She gave up and died... in anger and in shame. Yes, she had her pride!
The old firm eh? Hoskins and Randall...
Put like that our operations were practically a moral crusade. Our only aim in life was to make people happy. Hoskins did the fixing. I sailed the boat.
